description: From Latin autographum, in turn from Ancient Greek αὐτόγραφον (autógraphon, “a writing in one’s own hand”). Equivalent to auto- +‎ -graph.

entries.meaning: Written in the author’s own handwriting.
(art) Made by the artist himself or herself; authentic.
examples: Schiff  […]  believes most of the drawings are autograph.

entries.meaning: A person’s own handwriting, especially the signature of a famous or admired person.
examples: Some autograph-hunters were pestering the players after the game.

entries.meaning: (by extension, colloquial) A person's signature used as a mark of formal approval.
examples: If you could just put your autograph on the ol' contract, please...

entries.meaning: A manuscript in the author’s handwriting.

verbs.description: autograph (third-person singular simple present autographs, present participle autographing, simple past and past participle autographed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To sign, or write one’s name or signature on a book etc
(transitive) To write something in one's own handwriting
